headline.main: THE TEMPERANCE MOVEMENT.; History and Progress of the Temperance Cause. Efforts of Dr. Nott and E. C. Delavan.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Temperance cause, the Temperance movement, the Temperance reform, or by whatever name it may be called, must now he regarded as a fixed fact in our modern history. It has taken a hold of the public mind, deeper than the most sanguine would once have ventured to predict It has gone beyond this: it has penetrated the public conscience. It has entered into our stock of public

headline.main: LATEST INTELLIGENCE.; By Telegraph of the New-York Daily Times. IMPORTANT FROM THE CAPITAL. Hon. J. Walker's Resignation, Appointments, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hon. J. WALKER'S resignation of the Chinese mission has been accepted. The cause of his resignation is believed to be a remonstrance of his relatives against going, as his health does not improve as rapidly as promised when he accepted the appointment. The appointment of a successor may be expected at an early day.

byline.original: Special Dispatch to the New York Daily Times

docs.lead_paragraph: THE HEALTH OF THE CITY.--Our report of to-day, as well as those for several days past, show a most encouraging and promising decrease in the amount of morality. The decrease has been steady for more than a week, and will undoubtedly continue so until the subsidence of the epidemic--a period very near at hand, if the present very favorable weather continues.

headline.main: NEW-YORK CITY.; COMMON COUNCIL PROCEDINGS. COMMENCEMENT OF SEPTEMBER SESSION. Annual Report of the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department. Board of Assistant Aldermen. New-York and Brooklyn Foreign Missionary Society. Court of General Sessions. Board of Supervisors. OFFAL AND NIGHT-SOIL REMOVED FROM THE CITY. THE TROUBLE ON THE SHIP ANGELIQUE. LETTER FROM MR. JAMES T. BRADY. RE-DEDICATION OF A CHURCII. THE SEPTEMBER TERM OF THE COURTS. ALLEGED FRAUD. AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY. JUSTICE BOGART AND THE CORPORATION ORDINANCES FIRES. DROWNED. THE CATTLE ROBBERY. JUMPING AFTER A FERRY-BOAT. POLICE DOINGS. COWARDLY ATTACK. SUDDEN DEATH. TERRIBLE AFFRAY AND BLOODSHED. SUDDEN DEATH. EXPLOSION OF A FLUID LAMP. SAD ACCIDENT. A SOLDIER DROWNED. OWNER WANTED. COURT CALENDAR--TUESDAY. SUPREME COURT UNITED STATES MARSHAL's OFFICE. SUPREME COURT-SPECIAL TERM. SUPREME COURT CIRCUIT.

docs.lead_paragraph: The September Session of the Common Council commenced yesterday afternoon. The proceedings in the Board of Aldermen were quite interesting. The Annual Report of the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department was received, and is given below. A number of petitions were presented in the Board of Aldermen and appropriately referred.

headline.main: Affairs in Mexico--Speeches of Santa Anna and Minister Conkling.

SERMONS.; Discourses of Rev. J. P. Thompson, Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, Rev. Dr. Adams, and Rabbi Raphall. Discourse by Rev, Henry Ward Beecher. Madison-square Church--Rev. Dr. Adams. Aid to New-Orleans-Discourse of Rabbl Raphall.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Sunday morning. Rev. J. P. THOMPSON, Pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle, resumed his labors in his own pulpit, after his return from the Old World, where he has been sojourning for the past year, for the recovery of his health. headline.main: CHARITY.; Gratifying Comments from our Country Subscribers-The Five Points House of Industry.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The article in your paper of Tuesday last, headed, "Incidents of a day at the Five Points House of Industry," has not been without its fruits of good. Two letters reached Mr. PEASE yesterday enclosing valuable contributions. From one of these letters, dated "Mount Carmel," Ct., I extract the following:

docs.lead_paragraph: It will be recollected that Commodore NEWTON's death was published in most of the newspapers, which was erroneous, as he is still alive. He was, however, too ill to proceed in the Columbia (his flag-ship,) to San Juan de Nicaragua, with our Minister. Hon. SOLON BORLAND and suite. He therefore dispatched Commander PENDERGRAS??, with orders to proceed with our Minister to his place of destination, and the Commodore came north for his health.

headline.main: LATER FROM CUBA.; ARRIVAL OF THE CRESCENT CITY. Violation of American Official Correspondence. Post-Office Orders--Races--The Imprisoned American Sailors, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U. S. Mail steamship Crescent City, Lieut. SCHENCK, U. S. N., Commander, arrived at this port on Saturday. She left New-Orleans at 8 A. M., on the 26th ult, and Havana at 12 M. on the 29th ult. The returns, at the sailing of the Crescent City from New-Orleans, showed a slight decrease in the number of deaths from yellow fever.
